<ce:section-title id="sect0005">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0035" view="all">Two new Co(II) metal-organic frameworks, namely [Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bpm)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(L)]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and {[Co(bpe)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L)]·(bpe)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>·(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)}<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), (H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L=1,1′:2′,1″-terphenyl-3,3″,4′,5′-tetracarboxylic acid, bpm=bis(4-pyridyl)amine, bpe=1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethene), have been obtained under hydrothermal conditions. Both complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> have been characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectra, single-crystal X-ray diffraction, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). Complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> consist of 1D Co(II) chains bridging by carboxylate groups in <ce:italic>syn-anti</ce:italic> fashion. <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows a novel 3D tri-nodal (4,6,10)-connected net with a (3.4<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>.5<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(3<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.4<ce:sup loc="post">14</ce:sup>.5<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>.7<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>.8)(3<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.5<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>.7<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>) topology. While <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> exhibits a 2D <ce:bold>sql</ce:bold> layer. Magnetic susceptibility measurements indicate that both <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> show weak antiferromagnetic interactions between the adjacent Co(II) ions in 300–8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and 300–16<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, respectively, and then <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> also displays ferromagnetic coupling at lower temperatures.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Two new Co(II) metal-organic frameworks, namely [Co2(bpm)(H2O)3(L)] n  (1) and {[Co(bpe)(H2O)(H2L)]⋅(bpe)0.5⋅(H2O)} n  (2), (H4L=1,1':2',1"-terphenyl-3,3",4',5'-tetracarboxylic acid, bpm=bis(4-pyridyl)amine, bpe=1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethene), have been obtained under hydrothermal conditions. Both complexes 1 and 2 have been characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectra, single-crystal X-ray diffraction, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). Complexes 1 and 2 consist of 1D Co(II) chains bridging by carboxylate groups in syn-anti fashion. 1 shows a novel 3D tri-nodal (4,6,10)-connected net with a (3.43.52)2(32.414.512.612.74.8)(32.42.55.64.72) topology. While 2 exhibits a 2D sql layer. Magnetic susceptibility measurements indicate that both 1 and 2 show weak antiferromagnetic interactions between the adjacent Co(II) ions in 300-8K for 1 and 300-16K for 2, respectively, and then 2 also displays ferromagnetic coupling at lower temperatures.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sect0010">Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0040" view="all">Two Co(II) coordination polymers with similar metal chain bridging by carboxylates in <ce:italic>syn-anti</ce:italic> fashion have been synthesized. Both <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> show weak antiferromagnetic interactions in high temperature, and then <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> also displays ferromagnetic coupling at lower temperatures.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

Two Co(II) coordination polymers with similar metal chain bridging by carboxylates in syn-anti fashion have been synthesized. Both 1 and 2 show weak antiferromagnetic interactions in high temperature, and then 2 also displays ferromagnetic coupling at lower temperatures.

Highlights

   ⋅ Two Co(II) coordination polymers with similar metal chain bridging by carboxylates.   ⋅ A novel 3D (4,6,10)-connected net and a 2D sql layers.   ⋅ A antiferromagnetic coupling at high temperature for 1 and 2.   ⋅ A ferromagnetic coupling at lower temperature for 2.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0030">
<ce:link locator="fx1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>

<ce:para id="p0005" view="all">Two Co(II) coordination polymers with similar metal chain bridging by carboxylates.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0010" view="all">A novel 3D (4,6,10)-connected net and a 2D <ce:bold>sql</ce:bold> layers.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0015" view="all">A antiferromagnetic coupling at high temperature for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0020" view="all">A ferromagnetic coupling at lower temperature for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>.</ce:para><ce:section-title id="sect0025">Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0025" view="all">Magnetic materials based on transition metal ions with polynuclear units, such as Co(II) and Mn(II), have been extensively studied because a high spin ground state can be obtained from strong exchange interactions between 3d electrons . The huge diversity and versatility of coordination and supramolecular chemistry have provided great opportunities to obtain new magnetic materials and to better understand fundamental magnetic phenomena . Coordination polymers (CPs) with polynuclear units based on Co(II) and Mn(II), occupy an important position as they represent a perfect combination of magnetic properties and structures . Generally, the construction of polynuclear-based MOFs is a rather complex process because these polynuclear units are often <ce:italic>in situ</ce:italic> generated in different reactions. Thus, the variable factors in the assembled processes, such as coordination modes of metal centers and multicarboxylate ligands, will make significant structural changes of the resulting clusters. Multicarboxylate ligands, which are widely employed to construct such extended architectures, not only bind several metal centers of specific coordination geometry to form polynuclear units but also can transmit the magnetic interaction . As a derivative of 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylic acid, 1,1′:2′,1″-terphenyl-4,4′,4″,5-tetracarboxylic acid, a more flexible and bigger ligand, can adopt various coordination modes and allowing higher dimensionality structures. So it has been employed to construct CPs . However, polymetallic clusters of 1,1′:2′,1″-terphenyl-3,3″,4′,5′-tetracarboxylic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L), an isomeric tetracarboxylic acid, with transition metal is rare until now .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Two Co(II) coordination polymers with similar metal chain bridging by carboxylates.

A novel 3D (4,6,10)-connected net and a 2D sql layers.

A antiferromagnetic coupling at high temperature for 1 and 2.

A ferromagnetic coupling at lower temperature for 2.

Introduction

Magnetic materials based on transition metal ions with polynuclear units, such as Co(II) and Mn(II), have been extensively studied because a high spin ground state can be obtained from strong exchange interactions between 3d electrons . The huge diversity and versatility of coordination and supramolecular chemistry have provided great opportunities to obtain new magnetic materials and to better understand fundamental magnetic phenomena . Coordination polymers (CPs) with polynuclear units based on Co(II) and Mn(II), occupy an important position as they represent a perfect combination of magnetic properties and structures . Generally, the construction of polynuclear-based MOFs is a rather complex process because these polynuclear units are often in situ generated in different reactions. Thus, the variable factors in the assembled processes, such as coordination modes of metal centers and multicarboxylate ligands, will make significant structural changes of the resulting clusters. Multicarboxylate ligands, which are widely employed to construct such extended architectures, not only bind several metal centers of specific coordination geometry to form polynuclear units but also can transmit the magnetic interaction . As a derivative of 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylic acid, 1,1':2',1"-terphenyl-4,4',4",5-tetracarboxylic acid, a more flexible and bigger ligand, can adopt various coordination modes and allowing higher dimensionality structures. So it has been employed to construct CPs . However, polymetallic clusters of 1,1':2',1"-terphenyl-3,3",4',5'-tetracarboxylic acid (H4L), an isomeric tetracarboxylic acid, with transition metal is rare until now .

elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials and physical measurements

All solvents and reagents were available and were used as received. Elemental analysis for C, H and N was performed on a Flash 2000 organic elemental analyzer. Thermogravimetric analysis was performed on a NETZSCH STA 449C microanalyzer heated from 25 to 900°C in nitrogen atmosphere. Infrared spectra (4000-600cm-1) were recorded on a FTIR Nexus spectrophotometer spectrometer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were taken on a Rigaku Ultima IV diffractometer (Cu Kα radiation, λ=1.5406Å), with a scan speed of 5°/min and a step size of 0.02° in 2θ. Variable-temperature magnetic measurements were carried out on a Quantum Design SQUID MPMS XL-7 instrument (2-300K) in the magnetic field of 1kOe, and the diamagnetic corrections were evaluated by using Pascal's constants.

elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography

Single crystal X-ray diffraction data for complexes 1 and 2 were collected on a Rigaku XtaLAB mini diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ=0.71073Å) by using φ/ω scan technique. The structures were solved by direct methods and successive Fourier difference synthesis (SHELXS-97) , and refined by the full-matrix least-squares method on F 2 with anisotropic thermal parameters for all non-H atoms (SHELXL-97) . H atoms were assigned with isotropic displacement factors and included in the final refinement with geometrical restrains. Further crystallographic data are shown in  . Selected bond parameters for 1-2 are shown in . CCDC Reference no: 958449 for 1 and 958451 for 2.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sect0050">Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="sect0055">Synthetic chemistry</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">In this work, NaOH was used to neutralize the H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L. At first, a molar ratio of 2:1 between NaOH and H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L was used for preparation of the two complexes, and it is interesting to find out that the 3,3″-carboxylic group in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is protonated and free of coordination, while those in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were completely deprotonated. When the amount of NaOH used for preparation of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> was increased to 3 or 4 fold of H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L, and we only find that the homogeneous product with protonated 3,3″-carboxylate can be obtained by the same hydrothermal process.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Synthetic chemistry

In this work, NaOH was used to neutralize the H4L. At first, a molar ratio of 2:1 between NaOH and H4L was used for preparation of the two complexes, and it is interesting to find out that the 3,3"-carboxylic group in 2 is protonated and free of coordination, while those in 1 were completely deprotonated. When the amount of NaOH used for preparation of 2 was increased to 3 or 4 fold of H4L, and we only find that the homogeneous product with protonated 3,3"-carboxylate can be obtained by the same hydrothermal process.

L4- ligand adopts the (κ 1-κ 1)-(κ 1-κ 1)-(κ 2)-(κ 1)-μ 5 coordination fashion to bridge two Co1, two Co2 and one Co3 ( a). The Co(II) atoms are bridged by carboxylate groups in syn-anti modes to form a 1D chain with the Co⋅⋅⋅Co distances of 5.28 and 5.34Å, respectively (b). In such 1D chains, there are two kinds of Co(II)-based subunits: one is the trinuclear units [Co3N4(COO)4]2+ that consists of two [Co1O5N] and one [Co3O4N2] with the Co⋅⋅⋅Co distances of 5.28. Another is [Co2O6] units. Such 1D chains are further interlinked by L4- and bpm ligands to form a 3D network (see c).

elements.clean_text: {[Co(bpe)(H  2  O)(H  2  L)]⋅(bpe)  0.5  ⋅(H  2  O)}   n   (2). The asymmetric unit of compound 2 contains a Co(II) ions, one bpe, one H2L2-, one coordinated water, and half of a bpe as well as one free water. As shown in  a, Co1 is six-coordinated with a distorted octahedron geometry by three carboxylato-O atoms from three H2L2- ligands (O1, O3, and O2#1), one coordination water molecule (O9) and two trans-nitrogen atoms from two bpe (N1 and N2#2). In 2, 3,3"-carboxylic groups of H2L2 - is protonated and free of coordination, while the other two carboxylate groups of H2L2- ligand display (κ 1-κ 1)-(κ 1)-μ 2 coordination fashion to link two Co(II) atoms (b). Co(II) ions are linked by carboxylate groups in syn-anti fashion to form a 1D chain with the Co⋅⋅⋅Co distance of 5.25Å. Such 1D chains are further joined by bpe to generate a 2D sql layer (b). The 2D layers are further bound by hydrogen bonding interactions O(8)⋅⋅⋅O(4)#4 (d(O⋅⋅⋅O)=2.59Å,  ∠ (OHO)=164.6°, symmetry code: #4: -x+1,-y,-z) to generate a 3D supramolecular architecture (c). The free water and bpe molecules are located in the interlayer channels by hydrogen bonds O10⋅⋅⋅O(4)#7, O5⋅⋅⋅N(3)#3, (d(O⋅⋅⋅O)=3.05Å,  ∠ (OHO)=158.3°, d(O⋅⋅⋅N)=2.54Å,  ∠ (OHN)=171.8°, symmetry code: #3: x+1,y-1,z; #7: -x+1,-y,-z), confirmed by broad bands at region of 3700-2740cm-1 in IR spectra. These hydrogen bonding interactions not only brings further stability for the structure but also link the 2D sheets to form a 3D supramolecular architecture ().

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sect0065">PXRD and thermal properties</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0075" view="all">To confirm the phase purity of the bulk materials, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) have been carried out. The PXRD experimental and computer-simulated patterns are in good agreement with each other, indicating that both <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> phase purity of the as-synthesized products ().</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
PXRD and thermal properties

To confirm the phase purity of the bulk materials, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) have been carried out. The PXRD experimental and computer-simulated patterns are in good agreement with each other, indicating that both 1 and 2 phase purity of the as-synthesized products ().

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0080" view="all">The TGA curves of the two compounds are shown in . For complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the first weight lost of 6.6% was observed from 200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C to 270<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C corresponding to the lost of coordination water molecules (calcd. 7.2%). Then pyrolysis of the sample occurred from 270 to ~562<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. The final residue of 23.8% is close to the calculated 23.6% based on CoO. For complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the pyrolysis of the sample occurred from 230 to 540<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C.</ce:para>

For complex 1, the first weight lost of 6.6% was observed from 200°C to 270°C corresponding to the lost of coordination water molecules (calcd. 7.2%). Then pyrolysis of the sample occurred from 270 to ~562°C. The final residue of 23.8% is close to the calculated 23.6% based on CoO. For complex 2, the pyrolysis of the sample occurred from 230 to 540°C.

elements.clean_text:
Magnetic properties

The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibilities were measured on polycrystalline samples of 1 and 2 at 1000Oe in the range of 2-300K in  . For complexes 1 and 2, The value of χ M T at 300K is 2.78 and 3.47cm3 mol-1 K, respectively, which is much larger than the spin-only value (1.875cm3 mol-1 K) for one spin only Co(II) (S=3/2) ion, indicating the important orbital contribution arising from the high-spin octahedral Co(II) . Upon cooling, χ M T decreases to minimum value of 1.62cm3 mol-1 K at 3K for 1 and minimum value of 2.35cm3 mol-1 K at 12K for 2, and then increases to 1.70cm3 mol-1 K at 2K for 1 and 3.87cm3 mol-1 K at 2K for 2. Upon cooling, the decrease of χ M T at high temperature is a typical manner of spin-orbit coupling of Co(II) ions. The increases in χ M T under 12K for 2 are clearly indicative of ferromagnetism between neighboring Co ions . The temperature dependence of 1/χ M obeys the Curie-Weiss law with C=2.87cm3 Kmol-1 and θ=-12.80K above 12K for 1 and C=3.62cm3 Kmol-1 and θ=-13.80K above 25K for 2, revealing the presence of strong spin-orbit couplings.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0105" view="all">Complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are composed of similar 1D μ-COO bridged Co(II) chains bridging by carboxylate groups in <ce:italic>syn-anti</ce:italic> fashion, with the Co···Co distances of 5.28 and 5.34<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and 5.25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, respectively. So the magnetic interactions between Co(II) atoms can be ignored. The difference of magnetic behavior between <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> due to the coordination environments of Co(II) atoms in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. The Co(II) centers adopt coordination spheres including [Co1O<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>N], [Co2O<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>] and [Co3O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, and [CoO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. The slight distorted octahedron geometry [Co2O<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>] and [Co3O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and distorted octahedron geometry [Co1O<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>N] in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and [CoO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> will affect magnetic behavior.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Complexes 1 and 2 are composed of similar 1D μ-COO bridged Co(II) chains bridging by carboxylate groups in syn-anti fashion, with the Co⋅⋅⋅Co distances of 5.28 and 5.34Å for 1 and 5.25Å for 2, respectively. So the magnetic interactions between Co(II) atoms can be ignored. The difference of magnetic behavior between 1 and 2 due to the coordination environments of Co(II) atoms in 1 and 2. The Co(II) centers adopt coordination spheres including [Co1O5N], [Co2O6] and [Co3O4N2] for 1, and [CoO4N2] for 2. The slight distorted octahedron geometry [Co2O6] and [Co3O4N2] in 1 and distorted octahedron geometry [Co1O5N] in 1 and [CoO4N2] in 2 will affect magnetic behavior.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sect0075">Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0110" view="all">In summary, two Co(II)-MOFs with similar metal chain bridging by carboxylates have been prepared. The results reveal that the coordination frameworks can be well modulated by the different coordination modes of the carboxylic groups of multicarboxylate ligands with different degree of deprotonation and nature of N-donor auxiliary ligands. Weak antiferromagnetic interactions exist at high temperatures for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, respectively, and then <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> also displays ferromagnetic coupling at lower temperatures. Further synthesis, structures and properties studies of Co(II) based mixed-ligand coordination frameworks are under way in our lab.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, two Co(II)-MOFs with similar metal chain bridging by carboxylates have been prepared. The results reveal that the coordination frameworks can be well modulated by the different coordination modes of the carboxylic groups of multicarboxylate ligands with different degree of deprotonation and nature of N-donor auxiliary ligands. Weak antiferromagnetic interactions exist at high temperatures for 1 and 2, respectively, and then 2 also displays ferromagnetic coupling at lower temperatures. Further synthesis, structures and properties studies of Co(II) based mixed-ligand coordination frameworks are under way in our lab.

Preparation of complexes 1 and 2.

 [Co2(bpm)(H2O)3(L)] n  (1) A mixture of H4L (0.1mmol, 40.6mg), bpm (0.10mmol, 17.1mg), Co(ClO4)2⋅6H2O (0.20mmol, 73.2mg), NaOH (0.2mmol, 8mg) was placed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (25mL), heated to 140°C for 3 days, and then cooled to room temperature over 24h. Red prism crystals were obtained. Yield: 41.0mg, 55% (based on H4L). Elemental analysis (%): calcd for (C32H25Co2N3O11): C, 51.56; H, 3.38; N, 5.64; Found: C, 51.46; H, 3.44; N, 5.57. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3442w, 1602s, 1523s, 1418s, 1394s, 1215m, 1024m, 809s, 754s.

 {[Co(bpe)(H  2  O)(H  2  L)]⋅(bpe)  0.5  ⋅(H  2  O)}   n   (2). 2 was synthesized in the similar way as that described for 1, except that bpm was replaced by bpe (0.20mmol, 36.4mg). Purple block crystals were obtained. Yield: 40.2mg, 52% (based on H4L). Elemental analysis (%): calcd for (C40H31CoN3O10): C, 62.18; H, 4.04; N, 5.44; Found: C, 62.09; H, 4.09; N, 5.50. <ce:section-title id="sect0005">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0035" view="all">Two new Co(II) metal-organic frameworks, namely [Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bpm)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(L)]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and {[Co(bpe)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L)]·(bpe)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>·(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)}<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), (H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L=1,1′:2′,1″-terphenyl-3,3″,4′,5′-tetracarboxylic acid, bpm=bis(4-pyridyl)amine, bpe=1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethene), have been obtained under hydrothermal conditions. Both complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> have been characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectra, single-crystal X-ray diffraction, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). Complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> consist of 1D Co(II) chains bridging by carboxylate groups in <ce:italic>syn-anti</ce:italic> fashion. <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows a novel 3D tri-nodal (4,6,10)-connected net with a (3.4<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>.5<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(3<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.4<ce:sup loc="post">14</ce:sup>.5<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>.7<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>.8)(3<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.5<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>.7<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>) topology. While <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> exhibits a 2D <ce:bold>sql</ce:bold> layer. Magnetic susceptibility measurements indicate that both <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> show weak antiferromagnetic interactions between the adjacent Co(II) ions in 300–8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and 300–16<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, respectively, and then <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> also displays ferromagnetic coupling at lower temperatures.</ce:simple-para><ce:para id="p0080" view="all">The TGA curves of the two compounds are shown in . For complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the first weight lost of 6.6% was observed from 200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C to 270<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C corresponding to the lost of coordination water molecules (calcd. 7.2%). Then pyrolysis of the sample occurred from 270 to ~562<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. The final residue of 23.8% is close to the calculated 23.6% based on CoO. For complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the pyrolysis of the sample occurred from 230 to 540<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C.</ce:para><ce:section-title id="sect0070">Magnetic properties</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0085" view="all">The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibilities were measured on polycrystalline samples of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> at 1000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Oe in the range of 2–300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K in <ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>
. For complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, The value of <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>T</ce:italic> at 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K is 2.78 and 3.47<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, respectively, which is much larger than the spin-only value (1.875<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K) for one spin only Co(II) (<ce:italic>S</ce:italic>=3/2) ion, indicating the important orbital contribution arising from the high-spin octahedral Co(II) . Upon cooling, <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>T</ce:italic> decreases to minimum value of 1.62<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K at 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and minimum value of 2.35<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K at 12<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, and then increases to 1.70<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K at 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and 3.87<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K at 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. Upon cooling, the decrease of <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>T</ce:italic> at high temperature is a typical manner of spin–orbit coupling of Co(II) ions. The increases in <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>T</ce:italic> under 12<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are clearly indicative of ferromagnetism between neighboring Co ions . The temperature dependence of 1/<ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>

cln_elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Two new Co(II) metal-organic frameworks, namely [Co2(bpm)(H2O)3(L)] n  (1) and {[Co(bpe)(H2O)(H2L)]⋅(bpe)0.5⋅(H2O)} n  (2), (H4L=1,1':2',1"-terphenyl-3,3",4',5'-tetracarboxylic acid, bpm=bis(4-pyridyl)amine, bpe=1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethene), have been obtained under hydrothermal conditions. Both complexes 1 and 2 have been characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectra, single-crystal X-ray diffraction, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). Complexes 1 and 2 consist of 1D Co(II) chains bridging by carboxylate groups in syn-anti fashion. 1 shows a novel 3D tri-nodal (4,6,10)-connected net with a (3.43.52)2(32.414.512.612.74.8)(32.42.55.64.72) topology. While 2 exhibits a 2D sql layer. Magnetic susceptibility measurements indicate that both 1 and 2 show weak antiferromagnetic interactions between the adjacent Co(II) ions in 300-8K for 1 and 300-16K for 2, respectively, and then 2 also displays ferromagnetic coupling at lower temperatures.

The TGA curves of the two compounds are shown in . For complex 1, the first weight lost of 6.6% was observed from 200°C to 270°C corresponding to the lost of coordination water molecules (calcd. 7.2%). Then pyrolysis of the sample occurred from 270 to ~562°C. The final residue of 23.8% is close to the calculated 23.6% based on CoO. For complex 2, the pyrolysis of the sample occurred from 230 to 540°C.

Magnetic properties

The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibilities were measured on polycrystalline samples of 1 and 2 at 1000Oe in the range of 2-300K in  . For complexes 1 and 2, The value of χ M T at 300K is 2.78 and 3.47cm3 mol-1 K, respectively, which is much larger than the spin-only value (1.875cm3 mol-1 K) for one spin only Co(II) (S=3/2) ion, indicating the important orbital contribution arising from the high-spin octahedral Co(II) . Upon cooling, χ M T decreases to minimum value of 1.62cm3 mol-1 K at 3K for 1 and minimum value of 2.35cm3 mol-1 K at 12K for 2, and then increases to 1.70cm3 mol-1 K at 2K for 1 and 3.87cm3 mol-1 K at 2K for 2. Upon cooling, the decrease of χ M T at high temperature is a typical manner of spin-orbit coupling of Co(II) ions. The increases in χ M T under 12K for 2 are clearly indicative of ferromagnetism between neighboring Co ions . The temperature dependence of 1/χ M obeys the Curie-Weiss law with C=2.87cm3 Kmol-1 and θ=-12.80K above 12K for 1 and C=3.62cm3 Kmol-1 and θ=-13.80K above 25K for 2, revealing the presence of strong spin-orbit couplings.

In this equation,   x = λ / k T  , ( λ  is the spin-coupling parameter and A is a measure of the crystal field strength due to the inter-electronic repulsions). The best fits gave the parameters λ=-135cm-1, A=1.03 and θ=0.19K for 1 and λ=-134cm-1, A=1.46 and θ=4.30K for 2. The positive θ values confirm the presence of ferromagnetic interactions.

The data were fitted as the noncritical-scaling theory with the following simple phenomenological Eq. :  (2)     Χ M   T = A exp  ( -   E 1   / k T )  + B exp  ( -   E 2   / k T )     where A+B is the high-temperature Curie constant, E 1/k for the effects of both spin-orbit coupling and site distortion, and the value E 1/k corresponding to spin coupling between Co(II) ions  The best fits gave the parameters A=1.26cm3 mol-1 K, E 1/k=46.64K, B=1.65cm3 mol-1 K, and E 2/k=-0.005K for 1 and A=1.66cm3 mol-1 K, E 1/k=72.12K, B=2.13cm3 mol-1 K, and E 2/k=-1.09K for 2.
